Award.AwardTitle: Development and Characterization of Durable Geopolymer Composites for Truly Sustainable Infrastructure Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research project is to develop a novel design methodology for a class of fiber-reinforced composite materials, combining the greenness of geopolymers with the enhanced durability of Engineered Cementitious Composites (ECC). Sustainable alternatives to energy intensive, high carbon footprint, Ordinary Portland Cement (OPC)-based building materials are needed in order to meet the needs of both new construction and to maintain existing infrastructure in harmony with the natural environment. True sustainability demands both material greenness and enhanced durability, which lowers the need for costly and environmentally unfriendly repair work. These new Engineered Geopolymer Composites (EGCs) will provide a highly sustainable alternative to OPC-based materials for infrastructure systems, an alternative that is badly needed and not currently provided by any other materials.

On a societal level, this project will touch the life of every person by producing truly sustainable construction materials that substantially lower the energy consumption and carbon production of the building and construction industries. Replacing even one percent of OPC-based materials with EGCs would be equivalent to taking millions of cars off of the road. Further, the novel design methodology will be adaptable to numerous fields beyond civil engineering, leading to more efficient materials development elsewhere. Locally, high school and college students will benefit as the results of the research are incorporated into classes (both at the university and through remote learning) and demonstration projects. The research will also be incorporated into an established local pre-college engineering program, intended to increase the number of minority students in engineering.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

Performance_Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

POR.DRECONTENT:
Development and Characterization of Durable Geopolymer Composites for Truly Sustainable Infrastructure Applications

True sustainability in buildings and construction demands both material greenness and enhanced durability. It is well known that production of Ordinary Portland Cement (OPC), a typical construction material today, involves large amounts of energy consumption and carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions. Besides, intensive or frequent repair and maintenance of infrastructure also causes considerable adverse environmental impacts. Therefore, genuinely sustainable infrastructure materials should be not only green but also durable for enhancing infrastructure sustainability over its life cycle.

This project aims to develop green and durable fiber reinforced geopolymer composites and characterize their mechanical, environmental, and durability properties. This entirely new family of sustainable materials, named Engineered Geopolymer Composite (EGC), is achieved by combining the greenness of geopolymers, a promising alternative to OPC which utilizes industrial byproducts, with the enhanced durability of Engineered Cementitious Composite (ECC), known as bendable concrete. A novel synergistic design methodology is developed in this research to facilitate efficient and systematic development of EGC. Specifically, this research accomplishes the following objectives:

 

  1. Develop a new design methodology that integrates micromechanics, design of experiment (DOE), and life cycle analysis (LCA) techniques.
  2. Develop fiber reinforced geopolymer composites with high material greenness and high tensile ductility. Specifically, the developed EGCs exhibit tensile strain hardening behavior and high ductility (preferably over 3%) several hundred times that of normal concrete, with self-controlled tight cracks (preferably less than 50 microns). These unique engineering properties provide enhanced durability of infrastructure.
  3. Evaluate the sustainability of developed EGC materials based on their mechanical, environmental, and durability properties, in comparison of conventional cement concrete and ECC.

 

Intellectual Merits: The proposed concept of the combination of high material greenness and high durability in one concrete material has the potential to make a paradigm shift in the field. This new approach is a leap forward in science and engineering for sustainable infrastructure materials, where either materials greening or durability enhancement has been solely attempted. Additionally, the new material design methodology developed in this project is applicable to not only fiber reinforced composites for civil infrastructure but also other composite materials for various applications in other industrial sectors. As the involved design techniques (micromechanical modeling, DOE, and LCA) have not been fully applied in the geopolymer research community, the knowledge gaps in the state-of-the-art geopolymer technology were filled in. Due to the broad subjects involved, the graduate students trained on this project acquired wide-ranging and in-depth knowledge and experience. They will serve to disseminate the EGC and the relevant technologies both in the United States and abroad.

 

Broader Impacts: The EGC materials developed in this project contribute to achievement of truly sustainable infrastructure applications. Energy consumption and carbon production in the construction industry can be substantially lowered by employing EGC for infrastructure. Even partial replacement of OPC-based concrete with EGC could considerably reduce environmental, social, and economic costs of our society. In addition, since the developed EGC materials and the synergistic design methodology are entirely new, the outcomes of this project have the ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Development and Characterization of Durable Geopolymer Composites for Truly Sustainable Infrastructure Applications True sustainability in buildings and construction demands both material greenness and enhanced durability. It is well known that production of Ordinary Portland Cement (OPC), a typical construction material today, involves large amounts of energy consumption and carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions. Besides, intensive or frequent repair and maintenance of infrastructure also causes considerable adverse environmental impacts. Therefore, genuinely sustainable infrastructure materials should be not only green but also durable for enhancing infrastructure sustainability over its life cycle. This project aims to develop green and durable fiber reinforced geopolymer composites and characterize their mechanical, environmental, and durability properties. This entirely new family of sustainable materials, named Engineered Geopolymer Composite (EGC), is achieved by combining the greenness of geopolymers, a promising alternative to OPC which utilizes industrial byproducts, with the enhanced durability of Engineered Cementitious Composite (ECC), known as bendable concrete. A novel synergistic design methodology is developed in this research to facilitate efficient and systematic development of EGC. Specifically, this research accomplishes the following objectives: Develop a new design methodology that integrates micromechanics, design of experiment (DOE), and life cycle analysis (LCA) techniques. Develop fiber reinforced geopolymer composites with high material greenness and high tensile ductility. Specifically, the developed EGCs exhibit tensile strain hardening behavior and high ductility (preferably over 3%) several hundred times that of normal concrete, with self-controlled tight cracks (preferably less than 50 microns). These unique engineering properties provide enhanced durability of infrastructure. Evaluate the sustainability of developed EGC materials based on their mechanical, environmental, and durability properties, in comparison of conventional cement concrete and ECC. Intellectual Merits: The proposed concept of the combination of high material greenness and high durability in one concrete material has the potential to make a paradigm shift in the field. This new approach is a leap forward in science and engineering for sustainable infrastructure materials, where either materials greening or durability enhancement has been solely attempted. Additionally, the new material design methodology developed in this project is applicable to not only fiber reinforced composites for civil infrastructure but also other composite materials for various applications in other industrial sectors. As the involved design techniques (micromechanical modeling, DOE, and LCA) have not been fully applied in the geopolymer research community, the knowledge gaps in the state-of-the-art geopolymer technology were filled in. Due to the broad subjects involved, the graduate students trained on this project acquired wide-ranging and in-depth knowledge and experience. They will serve to disseminate the EGC and the relevant technologies both in the United States and abroad. Broader Impacts: The EGC materials developed in this project contribute to achievement of truly sustainable infrastructure applications. Energy consumption and carbon production in the construction industry can be substantially lowered by employing EGC for infrastructure. Even partial replacement of OPC-based concrete with EGC could considerably reduce environmental, social, and economic costs of our society. In addition, since the developed EGC materials and the synergistic design methodology are entirely new, the outcomes of this project have the potential to create a new research and development opportunities for academic institutions and innovative commercial enterprises.
